facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated October 10, 1958 of the Madras High Court in O.S. Appeal No. 1 of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree, dated October 10, 1958 of the Madras High Court in O.S. Appeal No. 1 of 1954. V. R. Tatachari, for the appellant.

facts.text: Appellant executed a promissory note at Madras for Rs. 10,600 in favour of Narayana Iyer on January 28, 1946 and agreed to pay interest at 12% p.a.

anchor.surface_text: Admittedly the appellant had executed a promissory numbere at Madras for a sum of Rs. 10,600 in favour of one Narayana Iyer, since deceased, on January 28, 1946 and agreed to pay interest on that amount at 12 p.a.

facts.text: No repayment was made by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It is also admitted that numberrepayment was made by the appellant. Narayana Iyer, therefore, instituted a suit against him for recovery of a sum of Rs. 14,402-5-0,

facts.text: Narayana Iyer instituted a suit against appellant for recovery of Rs. 14,402-5-0 including interest.

anchor.surface_text: Narayana Iyer, therefore, instituted a suit against him for recovery of a sum of Rs. 14,402-5-0, which includes interest upon the sum of Rg. 10,600. The appellant companytended that the promissory numbere was only a renewal

facts.text: Appellant contended that the 1946 promissory note was a renewal of previous promissory notes back to original for Rs. 1,000 executed in 1930 by his brother.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that the promissory numbere was only a renewal of a previous promissory numbere which itself as well as three earlier promissory numberes were in renewal of the original promissory numbere for Rs. 1,000 executed in the year 1930.

facts.text: Original promissory note for Rs. 1,000 executed in 1930 by appellant's brother, renewed by appellant in 1932.

anchor.surface_text: According to the appellant that promissory numbere was executed by his brother but was renewed by the appellant himself in the year 1932 that this promissory numbere was renewed on January 11, 1937

facts.text: Promissory note renewed on January 11, 1937 by appellant for Rs. 4,000 including interest and additional Rs. 350, taken in name of General Bank under Narayana Iyer's control.

anchor.surface_text: that this promissory numbere was renewed on January 11, 1937 by him and that at that time Narayana Iyer had given an additional amount of Rs. 350 to him. The amount for which his promissory numbere was executed was Rs. 4,000 and it included interest on the first advance up to that date. Narayana lyer, however, instead of taking a promissory numbere in his own name took it in the name of General Bank

facts.text: Debt renewed in favour of General Bank on January 3, 1940 by promissory note for Rs. 5,650.

anchor.surface_text: which is a private limited companypany which admittedly was under his companytrol. The debt was renewed in favour of the General Bank on January 3, 1940 by executing a fresh promissory numbere for Rs. 5,650 on that date

facts.text: Promissory note renewed on September 13, 1944 for Rs. 9,275 in favour of General Bank.

anchor.surface_text: and again on September 13, 1944 when it was renewed by obtaining a promissory numbere for Rs. 9,275. According to the respondents Narayana lyer paid off the dues to the General Bank

facts.text: Respondents claimed Narayana Iyer paid off dues to General Bank at instance of appellant and obtained promissory note for Rs. 10,600.

anchor.surface_text: According to the respondents Narayana lyer paid off the dues to the General Bank at the instance of the appellant and obtained a promissory numbere in his favour for Rs. 10,600. As the amount was number paid, Narayana lyer instituted the suit

facts.text: Narayana Iyer died during pendency of the suit, represented by his sons, the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: As the amount was number paid, Narayana lyer instituted the suit out of which this appeal arises. He, however, died during the pendency of the suit and is number represented by his sons, the respondents.

facts.text: Appellant is an agriculturist entitled to benefits of Madras Agriculturists Relief Act IV of 1938.

anchor.surface_text: Upon the aforesaid facts and the further fact that the appellant is an agriculturist he claimed that he was entitled to the benefits of the Madras Agricul- turists Relief Act IV of 1938.

facts.text: Single Judge of Madras High Court upheld appellant's plea, decreed Rs. 1,350 with interest at 6 1/4% from March 22, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: His plea was upheld by the learned single Judge of the High Court who held that the respondents after scaling down the interest as provided in the Act were entitled to a sum of Rs. 1,350 together with interest thereon at 6 1/4 from March 22, 1938 up to the date of the decree.

facts.text: Madras High Court appellate bench in Letters Patent appeal decreed Rs. 10,600 plus interest at 6% p.a.

anchor.surface_text: In the appeal preferred by the respondents under the Letters Patent the appeal companyrt held that the respondents were entitled to a decree for the entire amount for which the promissory numbere was executed, that is, Rs. 10,600 together with interest thereon at 61 p.a.

facts.text: Madras Agriculturists Relief Act IV of 1938 received assent on March 11, 1938, published March 22, 1938, into force from March 11, 1938.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received assent of the Governor General on March 11, 1938 and was first published in the Official Gazette on March 22, 1938 and must be deemed to have companye into force as from the former date.

facts.text: High Court found Narayana Iyer paid Rs. 10,600 by cheque to General Bank to the credit of the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found as a fact by the appeal companyrt that Narayana Iyer actually paid Rs. 10,600 by cheque in favour of the General Bank Ltd., to the credit of the appellant.

facts.text: High Court found Narayana Iyer paid off the debt to Bank at request of appellant to discharge appellant's liability.

anchor.surface_text: It has also been found by the High Court that Narayana lyer paid off the debt due from the appellant to the Bank at the request of the appellant for discharging the appellants liability upon the promissory numbere executed by him in favour of the Bank.

facts.text: General Bank is a private limited company under control of Narayana Iyer.

anchor.surface_text: Narayana lyer, however, instead of taking a promissory numbere in his own name took it in the name of General Bank which is a private limited companypany which admittedly was under his companytrol.

facts.text: Appellant made no repayments before the execution of the promissory note in suit.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to refer to them because even according to the appellant he had number made any repayments before the execution of the promissory numbere in the suit.

facts.text: Explanation III to Section 8 of the Act as amended by Madras Act 24 of 1950 applies to the case.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that it is the explanation which was amended by Act 24 of 1950 which applies to the case before us.

facts.text: Promissory note dated January 3, 1940 and September 13, 1944 executed in favour of General Bank.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept this argument in the absence of any material to show that the Bank acted on his behalf when the appellant executed the promissory numberes, dated January 3, 1940 ,and September 30, 1944 in favour of the Bank.
In the appeal preferred by the respondents under the Letters Patent the appeal court held that the respondents were entitled to a decree for the entire amount
the benefits of the Madras Agricul- turists Relief Act IV of 1938. He claimed that under the provisions of that Act he was entitled to have the debts scaled down.

concepts.unlisted_label: Madras Agriculturists Relief Act IV of 1938
concepts.unlisted_description: Act providing relief to agriculturists by scaling down debts

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 of the Act provides that all debts payable by an agriculturist at the commencement of the Act shall be scaled down in accordance with the provisions of Chapter II.

concepts.interpretation: Provides for scaling down of all debts payable by agriculturist at commencement of Act

concepts.unlisted_description: Scaling down pre-1932 debts, discharge of interest

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section 1 thereof says that all interest outstanding on the 1st of October, 1937 against an agriculturist shall be deemed to be discharged and only the principal outstanding on that date shall be deemed to be the amount repayable

concepts.interpretation: Interest on Oct 1, 1937 discharged, principal only repayable

anchor.surface_text: The only explanation which is relevant is explanation III. This explanation has been twice amended. The original explanation was as follows Where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation III to Section 8, Madras Agriculturists Relief Act 1938
concepts.unlisted_description: Treatment of principal in renewed debts

anchor.surface_text: Where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document in favour of the same creditor the principal originally advanced by the creditor together with such sums, if any, as have been subsequently advanced as principal shall alone be treated as the principal sum repayable

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: by the agriculturist under this section. The amend

concepts.unlisted_description: Renewal in favour of same creditor only

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act 23 of 1948 substituted for it the following Where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document executed before or after the commencement of this Act, whether by the same or a different debtor and whether in favour of the same or a different creditor

concepts.unlisted_description: First amendment to Explanation III S.8

anchor.surface_text: This was amended by Madras Act 24 of 1950 and now runs thus Where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document executed before or after the commencement of this Act, whether by the same debtor or by his heirs, legal representatives or assigns or by any other person acting on his behalf or in his interest

concepts.interpretation: Applies to case; covers renewals by same/different debtor/creditor including acting on behalf/in interest

anchor.surface_text: It will be seen that under the original explanation the benefit of sub-s. 1 of s. 8 was available only in cases where the debt had been renewed in favour of the same, creditor as the one from whom it was originally obtained. ... By virtue of this explanation the benefit of s. 8 1 would be available in a case where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document and where that is done b i by the same debtor, or by his heirs, legal representatives or assigns or by any other person acting on his behalf or by any other person acting in his interest.

concepts.interpretation: Benefit available if renewal by same debtor etc. and in favour of same creditor or person acting on behalf/in interest; on facts, General Bank not acting in interest of Narayana Iyer as he paid off debt for appellant's benefit creating new debt

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court it was urged that when the appellant executed the promissory note dated January 28, 1946 Narayana Iyer acted in the interest of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contended that the promissory note was only a renewal of a previous promissory note which itself as well as three earlier promissory notes were in renewal of the original promissory note for Rs. 1,000 executed in the year 1930.

holdings.text: The Act received assent of the Governor General on March 11, 1938 and was first published in the Official Gazette on March 22, 1938 and must be deemed to have come into force as from the former date.

anchor.surface_text: The Act received assent of the Governor General on March 11, 1938 and was first published in the Official Gazette on March 22, 1938 and must be deemed to have come into force as from the former date.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Based on date of assent and publication, deemed in force from assent date.

holdings.text: It is the explanation which was amended by Act 24 of 1950 which applies to the case before us.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that it is the explanation which was amended by Act 24 of 1950 which applies to the case before us.

holdings.text: By virtue of this explanation the benefit of s. 8(1) would be available in a case where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document and where that is done by the same debtor or by his heirs, legal representatives or assigns or by any other person acting on his behalf or in his interest. Such a transaction will be entitled to the benefit of the Act if the renewal or fresh agreement is in favour of the same creditor or of any other person acting on his behalf or in his interest.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of this explanation the benefit of s. 8 1 would be available in a case where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document and where that is done b i by the same debtor, or by his heirs, legal representatives or assigns or by any other person acting on his behalf or by any other person acting in his interest. Such a transaction will be entitled to the benefit of the Act if the renewal or fresh agreement is in favour of a the same creditor or b of any other person acting in his behalf or c any other person acting in his interest.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual parsing of the structure of Explanation III distinguishing debtor and creditor conditions.

holdings.text: In the instant case though the debtor in the transaction of 1930 was stated to be the appellants brother, in all subsequent transactions it was the appellant who was the debtor It would follow, therefore, that the requirements of the explanation pertaining to the debtor are satisfied in the sense that the same person has been the debtor.

anchor.surface_text: In the instant case though the debtor in the transaction of 1930 was stated to be the appellants brother, in all subsequent transactions it was the appellant who was the debtor It would follow, therefore, that the requirements of the explanation pertaining to the debtor are satisfied in the sense that the same person has been the debtor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of debtor-side condition to facts; same debtor in relevant transactions.

holdings.text: The General Bank has an independent existence and even though the controlling interest therein was with Narayana Iyer and his family it would not be correct to say that there is an identity between that bank and Narayana Iyer.

anchor.surface_text: The General Bank has an independent existence and even though the controlling interest therein was with Narayana lyer and his family it would number be companyrect to say that there is an identity between that bank and Narayana lyer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Corporate entity has separate legal existence despite control.

holdings.text: We cannot accept this argument in the absence of any material to show that the Bank acted on his behalf when the appellant executed the promissory notes, dated January 3, 1940 ,and September 30, 1944 in favour of the Bank.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot accept this argument in the absence of any material to show that the Bank acted on his behalf when the appellant executed the promissory numberes, dated January 3, 1940 ,and September 30, 1944 in favour of the Bank.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lack of evidence that Bank acted on behalf of Narayana Iyer.

holdings.text: Even assuming that that is the meaning to be given to these words the argument of learned counsel cannot be sustained on the facts of this case.

anchor.surface_text: Even assuming that that is the meaning to be given to these words the argument of learned counsel cannot be sustained on the facts of this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Arguendo acceptance of meaning 'for the benefit of' but fails on facts.

holdings.text: It has been found as a fact by the appeal court that Narayana Iyer actually paid Rs. 10,600 by cheque in favour of the General Bank Ltd., to the credit of the appellant. It has also been found by the High Court that Narayana Iyer paid off the debt due from the appellant to the Bank at the request of the appellant for discharging the appellants liability upon the promissory note executed by him in favour of the Bank. These findings of the High Court have not been seriously challenged before us and in our opinion quite rightly.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Acceptance of lower court findings on payment at appellant's request for his benefit; not challenged.

holdings.text: In view of these findings the contention of learned counsel that the payment was made in the interest of the creditor cannot be sustained.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Facts show payment for debtor's benefit, not creditor's interest; Explanation III conditions not met; no scaling down.

justification_sets.label: "Acting on his behalf or in his interest" support

anchor.surface_text: It has been found as a fact by the appeal court that Narayana Iyer actually paid Rs. 10,600 by cheque in favour of the General Bank Ltd., to the credit of the appellant. It has also been found by the High Court that Narayana Iyer paid off the debt due from the appellant to the Bank at the request of the appellant for discharging the appellants liability upon the promissory numbere executed by him in favour of the Bank. These findings of the High Court have not been seriously challenged before us and in our opinion quite rightly. In view of these findings the contention of learned counsel that the payment was made in the interest of the creditor cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: It has been found as a fact by the appeal court that Narayana Iyer actually paid Rs. 10,600 by cheque in favour of the General Bank Ltd., to the credit of the appellant. It has also been found by the High Court that Narayana Iyer paid off the debt due from the appellant to the Bank at the request of the appellant for discharging the appellants liability upon the promissory numbere executed by him in favour of the Bank. These findings of the High Court have not been seriously challenged before us and in our opinion quite rightly. In view of these findings the contention of learned counsel that the payment was made in the interest of the creditor cannot be sustained.

anchor.surface_text: By virtue of this explanation the benefit of s. 8 1 would be available in a case where a debt has been renewed or included in a fresh document and where that is done b i by the same debtor, or by his heirs, legal representatives or assigns or by any other person acting on his behalf or by any other person acting in his interest. Such a transaction will be entitled to the benefit of the Act if the renewal or fresh agreement is in favour of a the same creditor or b of any other person acting in his behalf or c any other person acting in his interest.

It has been found as a fact by the appeal court that Narayana Iyer actually paid Rs. 10,600 by cheque in favour of the General Bank Ltd., to the credit of the appellant. It has also been found by the High Court that Narayana Iyer paid off the debt due from the appellant to the Bank at the request of the appellant for discharging the appellants liability upon the promissory numbere executed by him in favour of the Bank. These findings of the High Court have not been seriously challenged before us and in our opinion quite rightly. In view of these findings the contention of learned counsel that the payment was made in the interest of the creditor cannot be sustained.

In the instant case though the debtor in the transaction of 1930 was stated to be the appellants brother, in all subsequent transactions it was the appellant who was the debtor It would follow, therefore, that the requirements of the explanation pertaining to the debtor are satisfied in the sense that the same person has been the debtor.
